name: hydrazinecarboxamide, n-phenyl-
Reason: 1,3-dioxolane has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for comparison can be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The introduction of the n-phenyl group increases the molecular weight and size which generally raises the melting point. The dioxane-like bridging moiety also contributes to the melting point due to increased molecular rigidity. The hydrazine group introduces two additional phenolic hydroxyl groups, which can participate in hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by approximately +20 degrees Celsius. The carbonyl group introduces a polar carbonyl interaction, contributing approximately +30 degrees Celsius. The n-phenyl group introduces additional rigidity, contributing approximately +10 degrees Celsius. The presence of a methoxy group can also contribute to the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces, estimated at around +5 degrees Celsius.
